importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007, establishing himself as a prominent young talent in chess.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
The New York Times hired Naroditsky as a chess columnist in 2022, highlighting his influence in mainstream media.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2007 to 2025 spans Naroditsky’s rise from youth champion to global chess educator, including his online presence and media roles.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at age 29, leaving behind a legacy as a skilled player, educator, and digital media influencer.
He earned the title of grandmaster before high school and won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007.
Naroditsky became a prominent chess educator through accessible content, with over 340,000 followers on Twitch and nearly 500,000 subscribers on YouTube.
He was a columnist for The New York Times and a regular contributor to Chess Life magazine, increasing the visibility of chess in mainstream culture.
The 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis began with a moment of silence in his honor, underscoring his impact on the chess community.
The Charlotte Chess Center and the International Chess Federation praised him as a beloved educator and community pillar.
Naroditsky's family has requested privacy, emphasizing the importance of honoring his legacy through his passion for teaching and community engagement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster born and raised in the San Francisco Bay Area, died at age 29. He earned the grandmaster title before high school and gained international acclaim as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in 2007. After studying history at Stanford University, he became a prominent chess educator through accessible online content, with millions of followers on YouTube and Twitch. His work as a chess columnist for The New York Times and contributor to Chess Life magazine helped bring chess into mainstream culture. The Charlotte Chess Center and the International Chess Federation recognized his contributions, and the 2025 US Chess Championship honored him with a moment of silence. Naroditsky is remembered as a passionate educator and community pillar who made chess accessible and joyful for people around the world.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
